Fun Fact 1
belfast is second largest city on the island of ireland.
Fun Fact 2
northern ireland, along with england, scotland and wales make up the “united kingdom of great britain and northern ireland.”
Fun Fact 3
the land that makes up belfast has been occupied since the bronze age.
Fun Fact 4
the 5,000-year-old henge, known as giant’s ring, is located near belfast, and iron age hill fort remains still are present in the surrounding hills.
Fun Fact 5
while belfast stayed a small settlement during the middle ages, the city played a leading role in the industrial revolution and was ireland’s largest city around the early part of the 20th century.
Fun Fact 6

when the u.s. civil war disrupted europe’s cotton supply, irish linen experienced a revival. linen companies flourished, and belfast became the world’s largest linen-producing area, hence its nickname, linenopolis.
Fun Fact 7

its location at the mouth of the river lagan made belfast an ideal location for the shipbuilding industry. harland and wolff had the largest shipyard in the world when it built the rms titanic during 1911-1912.
Fun Fact 8

during the last part of the 19th century, large numbers of catholics began to migrate in to the prosperous protestant city of belfast in search of work. this migration brought tensions as catholics and protestants competed for jobs. as the minority, catholics felt discrimination.
Fun Fact 9

with a majority of the residents in the northern part of ireland being protestant descendants of colonists from great britain, the british parliament partitioned northern and southern ireland in 1921, creating northern ireland.
Fun Fact 10
the belfast “good friday” agreement of 1998 was seen as the end of the troubles.
Fun Fact 11
by 2014, the catholic population in belfast has risen to 49 percent, while the protestant population has dropped to 42 percent, according to bbc news.
Fun Fact 12

readily viewed from any area of the city, belfast’s famous cranes are called samson and goliath, still the biggest free-standing cranes anywhere in the world. they have been classified as official historical monuments.
Fun Fact 13
a series of hills flank the northwestern side of belfast, including divis mountain, black mountain and cavehill.
Fun Fact 14

cavehill is believed to have inspired author jonathan swift’s sleeping giant in his gulliver’s travels novel. when swift resided at lilliput cottage near the bottom of belfast’s limestone road, he imagined that the cavehill resembled the shape of a sleeping giant safeguarding the city.
Fun Fact 15
on average, it rains 157 days a year in belfast, less than scotland, but more than dublin.
Fun Fact 16
snow typically falls in belfast less than 10 days a year.
Fun Fact 17

opened in march, 2012 on the site of the former harland & wolff shipyard, the titanic belfast is a monument to belfast’s maritime heritage, featuring nine high-tech galleries amidst a crisscross of escalators and suspended walkways.
Fun Fact 18
actor liam neeson had his stage premier at belfast’s lyric theater. neeson was born in the town of ballymena, county antrim, located 28 miles northwest of belfast.
Fun Fact 19
women could hold any office at queen’s university in belfast, twelve years before they could study at oxford.
Fun Fact 20
surrounded by mountains that create a micro-climate conducive to horticulture, belfast contains 3,000 acres of parks, many of them forested.
Fun Fact 21

the botanic gardens palm house — designed by sir charles lanyon and built in the 1830s –is one of the earliest examples of a curvilinear and cast iron glass-enclosed greenhouse. the botanic gardens park also hosted a u2 concert in 1997.
Fun Fact 22
south of the belfast city center, the sir thomas and lady dixon park attracts thousands of visitors each year to its international rose garden. every july rose week features more than 20,000 blooms.
Fun Fact 23
led zeppelin’s stairway to heaven was first played live in the ulster hall.
Fun Fact 24
the obel tower is the tallest building in belfast, and in northern ireland.
Fun Fact 25

opened in 1788, the linenhall library is belfast’s oldest. it houses a large collection of work by writer robert burns, as well as more than 20,000 archive items relating to irish politics and culture. guided tours of the library are offered in the summer months.
Fun Fact 26
oscar wilde thought that there was only one beautiful building in belfast. it is now home to a marks and spencer department store.
Fun Fact 27
muriel's cafe bar is the narrowest bar in belfast.
Fun Fact 28
the crown bar, one of the most famous pubs in belfast, was originally a railway hotel dating to 1826 when the first train ran from belfast to lisburn.
